message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The combination of a growing lump, presence of small nodules, and fine needle aspiration cytology revealing malignant cells arranged in a row of cells are suggestive of invasive lobular carcinoma. Inflammatory carcinoma presents with erythema and warmth of the breast, while fibroadenoma presents as a well-circumscribed mobile mass. Invasive ductal carcinoma may also present similarly, but the fine needle aspiration cytology finding of malignant cells arranged in a row of cells is more typical for invasive lobular carcinoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of multiple small nodules on examination suggests invasive lobular carcinoma, which tends to spread diffusely rather than form a discrete mass. Fine needle aspiration cytology confirms malignant cells, ruling out fibroadenoma. Inflammatory carcinoma would present with redness and warmth rather than a discrete lump.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of small nodules bilaterally, non-tender and immobile, suggests a metastatic cancer, which is more commonly seen in invasive lobular carcinoma than in invasive ductal carcinoma or fibroadenoma. Inflammatory carcinoma is unlikely given the lack of inflammatory symptoms in the patient's presentation. The fine needle aspiration cytology of the lesions revealing malignant cells arranged in a row is suggestive of invasive lobular carcinoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of small nodules and fine needle aspiration cytology showing malignant cells arranged in a row of cells suggest the most likely diagnosis is invasive lobular carcinoma. Inflammatory carcinoma is usually painful with skin changes, fibroadenoma is typically non-cancerous and shows homogeneous growth, and invasive ductal carcinoma usually has a more irregular growth pattern.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of a single lump that is getting larger, as well as the diagnosis of malignant cells in a row, suggests invasive lobular carcinoma. Inflammatory carcinoma typically presents with redness and swelling of the breast, while fibroadenoma is a benign tumor. Invasive ductal carcinoma may present as a lump but the cells are not typically arranged in a row.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of small nodules on both sides suggests the possibility of bilateral breast cancer, which is more commonly seen in invasive lobular carcinoma. The fine needle aspiration cytology revealing malignant cells arranged in a row of cells is also consistent with invasive lobular carcinoma. Inflammatory carcinoma presents with redness and warmth of the breast, while fibroadenoma is usually painless and mobile. Invasive ductal carcinoma is the most common type of breast cancer but does not typically present with bilateral nodules.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation and fine needle aspiration cytology results suggest invasive lobular carcinoma. Fibroadenoma is typically a single, well-circumscribed mass and is not typically associated with nodules. Inflammatory carcinoma presents with erythema, warmth, and swelling of the breast. Invasive ductal carcinoma is the most common type of breast cancer, but the fine needle aspiration cytology results suggest a row of cells, which is more consistent with invasive lobular carcinoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of bilateral nodules and the fine needle aspiration cytology result suggest that the most likely diagnosis is invasive lobular carcinoma. Inflammatory carcinoma will cause redness, warmth, and swelling of the breast, which is not mentioned in the scenario. Fibroadenoma is a benign tumor and will not have malignant cells present. Invasive ductal carcinoma may also have malignant cells present, but the scenario notes that the fine needle aspiration cytology revealed cells arranged in a row, a characteristic feature of invasive lobular carcinoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of bilateral small nodules and cytology of malignant cells arranged in a row of cells suggest invasive lobular carcinoma. Inflammatory carcinoma presents with erythema and warm, edematous skin while fibroadenoma presents with a single unilateral breast mass. Invasive ductal carcinoma presents as a single, unilateral, firm mass with irregular borders.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of bilateral small nodules that are non-tender and immobile, and cytology revealing malignant cells arranged in a row of cells suggests invasive lobular carcinoma. Inflammatory carcinoma would present differently, with breast swelling and redness. Fibroadenoma would have a different appearance on mammography. Invasive ductal carcinoma could also be a possibility, but the clinical and cytology findings are more consistent with invasive lobular carcinoma.
